banner.description: The only one of the three island traditions still thriving is peat-cutting, as in here at South Uist.

posts.intro: The first stage was to cut the turf, as Peter Sutherland is doing at Delting. Turfs were re-laid later to keep the land neat. Drainage could be a problem on level ground, and these South Ronaldsay workers need to bail.
The biggest difference was the efficiency. In the Hebrides and Orkney cutting took two people (one to cut, one to lay out) but in Shetland one person did both.

Work involved families and neighbours spending long days on the moors, turning and heaping the peats. The Walker family (Kirsteen, Padraig, Anne, Donald) from South Uist, and Teenie Leslie and Winnie Leask at Tingwall - taking a break as another Orkney group had done long before.

If peat banks were distant, workers could stay at huts on the moorland for a few days while working. This was done in Shetland, and especially Lewis, as in this scene. In later times, people like Harry Williamson could arrive by road in Tingwall.
People took a dim view if peat-banks weren’t laid neatly. This Shetland example shows how it should be done.

Farmers ferried home their peats depending on the terrain. In rugged areas it went by packsaddle (the Westing), large loads moved by cart (Birsay) or across the sea (Whalsay), and peats came down hillsides by sled (Sandwick). Hebridean willow creels were unlike the Northern Isles’ straw baskets.

Peats were stacked to stop rain ruining them; the Shetland man is setting the outer edge whilst the Orcadian woman is laying the turf topping. Perfectionists took pride, and stacks were often a backdrop for a photo, like for Norman, Iris, and Sandra MacKenzie in their Sunday best at Sheshader, Lewis.

Puffins were salted in barrels as food in Shetland, and used as bait in St Kilda.The Sinclair family at Whalsay. Specific peat types were selected for cooking or drying grain because they’d burn slower or more intensely.

quotes.cite: “Two men can cut and cast in a day peats sufficient for the consumption of their families a whole year”
“The west end of the island is a most excellent peat moss, which not only supplies most of the inhabitants of Burray, but a good part of South Ronaldsay.”

“The peats are of excellent quality, and in great abundance. Fuel convenient also; for the peat banks are in many instances fifty feet from the dwellings of the people. In few instances is it a mile distant. The labour of preparing devolves on females, with the exception of cutting and spreading to dry, which is done by males.”

postsSecond.intro: Changes came in the 20th century. Peats were handled in bags and barrows, and in Shetland’s steeper districts like Weisdale, pulleys were used. Road transport meant lorries or tractors freighted bigger loads, as here at Lewis.

A factory near Stornoway operated from 1852 to 1874, heating peats to extract boat tar, lamp oil, and roofing pitch. After the founding engineer left, his successor ruined the successful scheme through mismanagement and embezzlement.

Today, few need peats, and those who do often buy them instead of undertaking the work by hand. The downside is often damage to moorland that hand-cutting never did. Which of these contrasting Lewis scenes will be islands peat in future?

There are few language links between the Hebrides and Northern Isles, but the Lewis tairsgeir and Norn torvsker come from the same word. Hebridean culture is stronger though, and Gaelic has 80 words pertaining to peats; we have very few.
